BERLIN Outgoing U.S. President Barack Obama says he plans to come back to Germany at least one more time -- to visit Munich's annual beer-swigging Oktoberfest.""It's wonderful to be back in Berlin. This is my sixth visit to Germany
column2: it will not be my last
column3: Obama told a joint news conference with German Chancellor Angela Merkel.""I have somehow continued to miss Oktoberfest so that's probably something that is better for me to do as a former president rather than as president. I'll have more fun
column4: he said.Around 7.5 million litres of beer are consumed each year at the Oktoberfest by locals and tourists alike
column5: many decked out in traditional lederhosen and dirndls.

column1: 3	3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-congress-funding-idUSKBN13C1W7	House Republicans pursue short-term government funding bill	"

WASHINGTON Republicans in the U.S. House of Representatives have decided to pursue a short-term measure to keep the government funded at current levels until March in order to give incoming President-elect Donald Trump more of a say on budget and appropriations issues
column2: lawmakers said on Thursday.The decision
column3: which surfaced as House Republicans prepared to meet Vice President-elect Mike Pence
column4: calls for replacing a funding measure that expires on Dec. 9 with a similar resolution that would run through March 31.Lawmakers said the short-term measure would allow Trump to have greater input on setting funding priorities for the remainder of fiscal year 2017
column5: which ends on Sept 30.""I think the new
column6: incoming government would like to have a say-so on how spending is allocated
column7: House Speaker Paul Ryan told reporters. ""And so we are working with ... the new Trump administration on the timing of that on the continuing resolution.""Democrats and some Republicans described the decision as a mistake that could lead to a more difficult appropriations task next year.

column1: Representative Hal Rogers
column2: who chairs the House Appropriations Committee
column3: expressed disappointment at the decision
column4: which suspends months of work by lawmakers and their staffs on full-scale appropriations bills Congress had intended to enact before year end.""I am extremely hopeful that the new Congress and the new administration will finish these bills
column6: adding that his panel would immediately begin working on the new measure
column7: known as a continuing resolution.Representative Charlie Dent
column8: a Republican member of Rogers' committee
column9: called the decision a mistake following an election in which Democrats were able to increase their Senate minority.

column1: It will be harder to pass an omnibus in March
column2: Dent said. ""And we'll have a smaller margin in the senate to help us. I'd rather clear the decks for a new administration. But apparently the new administration would like to be able to put their imprint on this.""House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi said the continuing resolution would only perpetuate uncertainty about government funding.

column1: They're making a big mistake for themselves. They're going to have a kettle of fish in March that they can't even imagine
column2: she said.Some conservative House Republicans have sought a continuing resolution that would expire at the same time as the legislative limit on the government debt. (Reporting by Susan Cornwell and David Morgan; Editing by Bill Trott and David Gregorio)"	['Trott'

column1: 4	4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-intelligence-military-idUSKBN13C0G8	U.S. Mideast intelligence analysts felt superiors distorted findings	"
By Idrees Ali
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Officials in the U.S. military's Central Command
column2: which oversees combat operations in the Middle East and South Asia
column3: were much more likely than counterparts elsewhere to believe superiors  distorted or suppressed their analyses
column4: according to a government intelligence survey.    Results of the December 2015 survey are likely to reinforce questions in Congress and elsewhere about whether the administration is pressuring officials to make over-optimistic claims about progress against Islamic State and the Taliban to help U.S. President Barack Obama leave office in January on a high note.    The Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI)     survey
column5: which had not been reported until now
column6: was one of the main topics of a House intelligence committee hearing on Thursday.    In one of its more striking findings
column7: only 36 percent of  Central Command officials surveyed said they were confident that their mid- and senior-level managers were not deliberately distorting or suppressing their analyses.The average for the other eight U.S. military commands
column8: which include those in the Pacific
column10: was 72 percent.Central Command directs the American military missions in Afghanistan
column12: Syria and elsewhere in the Middle East and South Asia. Its analysts typically assess intelligence such as potential targets for bombing and an enemy's strength.Asked if ""anyone attempted to distort or suppress analysis on which you were working in the face of persuasive evidence
column13: 40 percent of the CENTCOM respondents said yes
column14: compared to an average of 13 percent.

column1: The survey found that when that question was asked

column6: including 125 CENTCOM analysts and managers. It cautions
column9: ""care should be taken when broadly interpreting results"" for each command.

column9: into the President's daily intelligence briefing.Nevertheless

The Defense Department Inspector General is investigating the findings and is expected to issue a separate report

column1: 5	5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-democrats-sanders-idUSKBN13C24H	Sanders to build base outside of Washington in new Democratic post	"
By Valerie Volcovici
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Senator Bernie Sanders
column2: a former Democratic presidential candidate
column3: said on Thursday he will help rebuild party support outside of Washington and craft a new economic message for all Americans.Sanders
column4: who will become outreach chair on the Senate Democrats leadership team
column5: will try to engage Americans who feel disconnected from the political process. Sanders is an Independent from Vermont but tends to vote with Democrats.   ""The real action to transform America won't take place on Capitol Hill
column6: it will be in the grassroots America among millions struggling economically and young people
column7: Sanders said at a breakfast hosted by the Christian Science Monitor.Democrat Charles Schumer of New York
column8: elected the Senate's new minority leader on Wednesday
column9: said Sanders will join his 10-member leadership team. He wants to harness Sanders' popularity with young and working class voters during the hard-fought primary battle with Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton.

column1: Democrats are regrouping after the upset victory of Republican Donald Trump and after Republicans gained control of the Senate and House and made big gains in control of state legislatures.Sanders
column2: who will also become the ranking Democrat on the Senate Budget Committee
column3: said he will make sure the panel represents the needs of working families
column4: not billionaires.One problem for the Democrats is while they make the point that the economy is better off today than it was eight years ago
column5: it has not improved for the middle class for decades

column1: What the Democrats I think too often have ignored is that for the last forty years ... the middle class of this country has been shrinking

column3: saying that real wages have gone down while income inequality has risen.    Sanders said he supports fresh leadership for the Democratic National Committee
column4: the party's organization and has endorsed Congressman Keith Ellison

column7: who is a progressive and a Muslim
column8: reflects the diversity of the party

8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-idUSKBN13B1UR	Confusion over Trump's first talks with foreign leader	"
By Alistair Bell and Ginger Gibson
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON One day before U.S. President-elect Donald Trump's first meeting with a foreign leader
column2: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe
column3: Japanese officials said they had not finalized when or where in New York it would take place
column4: who would be invited
column5: or in some cases whom to call for answers.Uncertainty over the talks shows the difficulties in turning Trump from a freewheeling businessman into a sitting president with a watertight schedule and a fully functioning administration by his inauguration on Jan. 20.              Japanese and U.S. officials said on Wednesday the State Department had not been involved in planning the meeting
column6: leaving the logistical and protocol details that normally would be settled far in advance still to be determined.""There has been a lot of confusion
column7: said one Japanese official. The meeting was only agreed to last week and Trump and his advisers have been busy in meetings at his headquarters in Manhattan's Trump Tower in recent days to work out who gets which job in the new administration. While world leaders sometimes hold loosely planned bilateral meetings at regional summits
column8: it is unusual for foreign leaders to hold high-level diplomatic talks in the United States without detailed planning. Abe is on his way to an Asia-Pacific summit in Peru.State Department spokesman John Kirby said that to his knowledge
column9: Trump's transition team had not been in contact with the department either to discuss the transition of government or to seek information ahead of his meetings with foreign leaders.Trump is expected to use the Abe meeting to reassure Japan and other Asian allies rattled by his campaign rhetoric
column10: advisers to Trump said. But Trump
column11: a brash outsider with no diplomatic or government experience
column14: have differences on policy issues such as free trade.    Several Trump aides did not immediately answer requests on Wednesday for comment about the Abe visit or contact between the transition team and the State Department.   TRANSITION SPECULATION

column1: Speculation about top appointments to the Trump administration has intensified since the head of the team overseeing the transition
column2: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie
column3: was removed last week and replaced by Vice President-elect Mike Pence.Transition team officials said on Wednesday night that Trump planned to announce ""landing teams"" on Thursday that would begin setting up staff in key agencies
column4: like the State and Justice departments.

column1: They added in a conference call with reporters that those who begin working on the teams would have to sign an agreement not to lobby for five years after they leave the administration
column2: keeping with a Trump campaign promise to institute a ban on lobbying for executive branch employees. Trump on Wednesday denounced reports of disorganization in the team
column3: singling out the New York Times for saying world leaders have had trouble getting in touch with him since his upset victory over Democrat Hillary Clinton in the Nov. 8 presidential election.    The Republican real estate magnate said on Twitter he had taken ""calls from many foreign leaders despite what the failing @nytimes said. Russia
column4: U.K.
column8: a frequent target of Trump's Twitter blasts
column9: said on Tuesday that U.S. allies were ""scrambling to figure out how and when to contact Mr. Trump"" and blindly dialing in to Trump Tower to try to reach him.The newspaper said Trump was working without official State Department briefing materials in his dealings with foreign leaders.        ""The failing @nytimes story is so totally wrong on transition
column11: without specifying what it was in the article that was incorrect. ""It is going so smoothly. Also
column12: I have spoken to many foreign leaders.""    Trump and Pence had spoken to 29 foreign leaders
column13: the transition team said on Wednesday.

column1: Trump has mostly stuck to normal practice for a U.S. president-elect with the order in which he has spoken to foreign leaders on the phone since his election victory.But some of his contacts have stretched the limits of the usual procedure.     Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi
column2: an army general who seized power three years ago
column3: appears to have been the first leader to speak to Trump after the election
column4: ahead of closer allies like the leaders of Britain and Germany.Sisi's office called Trump last Wednesday and the incoming U.S. president told him it was ""the first international call he had received to congratulate him on winning the election."" Australian media reported that Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull was the second leader Trump spoke to
column5: after the Australian ambassador to the United States got Trump's personal phone number from Australian golfer and Trump friend Greg Norman. Trump also talked on the phone to the leaders of Britain
column7: Turkey and other allies.  But a phone call on Monday with Russian President Vladimir Putin
column8: in which the two men agreed to aim for ""constructive cooperation
column9: raised eyebrows among Democrats and traditionalist Republicans worried about a resurgent Moscow.

column1: Trump also met Britain's anti-EU Brexit campaigner Nigel Farage at Trump Tower last weekend
column2: ahead of any meeting with British Prime Minister Theresa May.State Department spokesman Kirby said: ""There's been no outreach to date"" from Trump's transition aides. ""But it's not for us to approve or disapprove of conversations that the president-elect is having or may have in the future with foreign leaders.""'ONLY ONE WHO KNOWS'

column1: Despite fevered speculation
column2: Trump has yet to say who will fill Cabinet positions such as secretary of state
column3: treasury secretary or defense secretary. His team said that was not unusual and was in line with the timing of the transition of Democrat Barack Obama to the White House after he won the presidency in 2008. Trump could add son-in-law Jared Kushner as a top White House adviser
column4: the Wall Street Journal reported on Wednesday. Kushner
column5: who is married to Ivanka Trump
column6: has been a central adviser during the campaign and transition. The Trump transition team has repeatedly denied it is seeking high-level security clearance for Kushner.A federal anti-nepotism law prohibits a president from hiring family members to serve in his administration
column7: but the Journal said it was not clear if the law applied to a position inside the White House. It added Kushner had indicated he would avoid the issue by not taking pay for any White House work.      Kellyanne Conway
column8: a senior Trump aide who served as his campaign manager
column9: said she did not think Kushner was seeking an official role in the White House.""I just hung up the phone with Jared
column11: Conway told reporters on Wednesday night. ""I think he just wants to be incredibly helpful to his father-in-law as he's been all along.""South Carolina Governor Nikki Haley will meet with Trump on Thursday
column12: the transition team said. She emerged on Wednesday as a potential candidate for secretary of state.After speculation emerged that JPMorgan Chase & Co Chief Executive Jamie Dimon remained a contender for treasury secretary
column13: the bank's stock price dropped. (Additional reporting by Doina Chiacu
column17: Lesley Wroughton and Eric Beech in Washington
column18: and Emily Stephenson in New York; Writing by Ginger Gibson; Editing by Bill Trott and Peter Cooney)"	['Trott'
